actions-list.actionItem: Yea and Nay vote pending.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 8282 — "To impose sanctions with respect to the International Criminal Court engaged in any effort to investigate, arrest, detain, or prosecute any protected person of the United States and its allies."
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 8580 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Carter (TX) moved that the committee rise.
On agreeing to the Self amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 241).
On agreeing to the Mast amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 240).
On agreeing to the Greene (GA) amendment; Failed by recorded vote: (Roll no. 239).
On agreeing to the Crane amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 238).
On agreeing to the Bost amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 237).
The Chair announced that that the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to the amendments to H.R. 8580, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 8580 — "Making appropriations for military construction, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of June 4.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 8580 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Carter (TX) moved that the committee rise.

At the conclusion of debate on the Self amendment No. 42, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Wasserman Schultz demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Self amendment No. 42.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Self,  numbered 42 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to prohibit funds to modify or remove any display of the Department of Veterans Affairs that bears the mission statement "To fulfill President Lincoln's promise 'to care for him who shall have borne the battle, and for his widow, and his orphan' by serving and honoring the men and women who are America's veterans."
On agreeing to the Rodgers (WA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Rodgers (WA) amendment No. 41.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Rodgers (WA),  numbered 41 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the Family Housing Operation and Maintenance, Air Force, account to emphasize the importance of housing oversight.
On agreeing to the Rodgers (WA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Rodgers (WA) amendment No. 40.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Rodgers (WA),  numbered 40 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the Medical Community Care account to express the need for the Department of Veterans Affairs to address emergency care coverage.
On agreeing to the Pfluger amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Pfluger amendment No. 39.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Pfluger,  numbered 39 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding to direct the Department of Veteran Affairs to collaborate with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to conduct a comprehensive study determining and identifying exposures associated with being a military aviator, connections between these exposures and various cancers, and prevalence of and mortality from specified cancers among those who served as active-duty aircrew.
On agreeing to the Peters amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Peters amendment No. 38.

actions-list.header: An amendment, offered by Mr. Peters,  numbered 38 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease appropriations for the Veterans Health Administration
actions-list.actionItem: Medical Services
On agreeing to the Peters amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Peters amendment No. 37.

actions-list.header: An amendment, offered by Mr. Peters,  numbered 37 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease appropriations for the Veterans Health Administration
actions-list.actionItem: Medical Services
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 36.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 36 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease Veterans Health Administration, Medical Services, by $1 million for furnishing Stellate Ganglion Block (SGB) therapy to personnel who elect to receive the treatment.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 35.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 35 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for grants for construction of State Extended Care Facilities to focus on creating or maintaining nursing homes for Americas World War II, Korean, and Vietnam Veterans.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 34.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 34 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the Board of Veterans Appeals to prioritize increasing processing speed for veteran casework.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 33.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 33 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the Veterans Health Administration's medical community care account to increase accessibility for in-home health care services for veterans.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 32.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 32 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for medical services at the Veterans Health Administration for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder in veterans.
On agreeing to the Ogles amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 31.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 31 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the Veterans Housing Benefit Program Fund for the development of improved informational materials regarding the relative benefits of a VA home loan versus other types of housing loans for different homebuyer profiles.
On agreeing to the Molinaro amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Molinaro amendment No. 29.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Molinaro,  numbered 29 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) account by $10 million to reinforce the importance of strengthening the VHA's Office of Mental Health and its work to assist veterans with disabilities and mental health and substance abuse challenges.

At the conclusion of debate on the Mast amendment No. 28, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Carter (TX) demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Mast amendment No. 28.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Mast,  numbered 28 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to ensure veterans can participate in state-approved medical marijuana programs. The amendment removes the current directive that prevents VA Medical Facility staff from recommending, making referrals, or completing forms and registering Veterans for participation in state-approved marijuana programs.
On agreeing to the Kiggans (VA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Kiggans (VA) amendment No. 22.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Kiggans (VA),  numbered 22 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the purpose of expressing the urgency of expeditiously and efficiently utilizing increased demolition funding on Navy and Marine Corps bases.
On agreeing to the Kiggans (VA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Kiggans (VA) amendment No. 21.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Kiggans (VA),  numbered 21 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the purpose of ensuring that the Department of Veterans Affairs fully funds and competently executes mental health care programs, with a special emphasis on suicide prevention and associated outreach.
On agreeing to the Kiggans (VA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Kiggans (VA) amendment No. 20.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Kiggans (VA),  numbered 20 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the purpose of ensuring that the Department of Veterans Affairs maintains sufficient medical care for veterans who reside in US Territories and Freely Associated States.
On agreeing to the Kiggans (VA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Kiggans (VA) amendment No. 19.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Kiggans (VA),  numbered 19 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease funding for the purpose of encouraging the approval and development of privatized housing for unaccompanied service members.
On agreeing to the James amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the James amendment No. 18.

An amendment, offered by Mr. James,  numbered 18 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease $3,250,000 to Medical Facilities for the building of a Community-based Outpatient Clinics and Mobile Medical Units to become more available for leasing, purchasing, and construction for VA hospital networks.
On agreeing to the Hageman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Hageman amendment No. 17.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Hageman,  numbered 17 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to prohibit funding made available by this act from being used by the VA to continue decommissioning mileage reimbursement kiosks at VA facilities.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 16, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Wasserman Schultz demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 16.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 16 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to strike funding for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Security Investment Program.

At the conclusion of debate on the Crane amendment No. 10, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Wasserman Schultz demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Crane amendment No. 10.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Crane,  numbered 10 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to prohibit the VA from using funds to submit a beneficiary's name to the NICS list based on VA's appointment of a fiduciary.
On agreeing to the Burchett amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Burchett amendment No. 9.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Burchett,  numbered 9 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to prohibit funds from being used to ban or remove the photograph "V-J Day in Times Square."

At the conclusion of debate on the Bost amendment No. 8, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Wasserman Schultz demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Bost amendment No. 8.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Bost,  numbered 8 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to require the Department of Veterans Affairs to apply the same access standards for Mental Health Residential Rehabilitation Treatment Program (MHRRTP) as for primary care, specialty care, and non-institutional extended care services.
On agreeing to the Bergman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Bergman amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Bergman,  numbered 2 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to increase and decrease the Medical Services account at the Department of Veterans Affairs to urge the Department of Veterans Affairs to report to Congress no later than 180 days following approval of midomafetamine-assisted treatments to treat PTSD under Section 505 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act on possible incorporation of treatments in the formulary of the Department and the justification for such determination.
On agreeing to the Bergman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Bergman amendment No. 1.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Bergman,  numbered 1 printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 to Increase and decrease the Medical and Prosthetic Research account at the Department of Veterans Affairs to express support for recently announced Department of Veterans Affairs funded research into psychedelic-assisted therapies to treat PTSD and depression, and to encourage the Department of Veterans Affairs to prioritize the proactive training of therapists to administer these treatments.
On agreeing to the Carter (TX) amendments; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1269, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 20 minutes of debate on the Carter (TX) amendment en bloc.

Amendments en bloc  offered by Mr. Carter (TX),  comprised of the following amendments printed in Part B of House Report 118-535 as en bloc: Nos. 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 30, and 47.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 8580.
The Speaker designated the Honorable John W. Rose to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 1269 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8580 and H.R. 8282. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 8580 under a structured rule and H.R. 8282 under a closed rule. Rule provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each bill.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1269. H.R. 8580 — "Making appropriations for military construction, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 8282, the Chair put the question on passage of the bill and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McCaul demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 8282.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 8580 and H.R. 8282. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 8580 under a structured rule and H.R. 8282 under a closed rule. Rule provides for one hour of general debate and one motion to recommit on each bill.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 1269. H.R. 8282 — "To impose sanctions with respect to the International Criminal Court engaged in any effort to investigate, arrest, detain, or prosecute any protected person of the United States and its allies."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 208
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 205

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 1269 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 8580) making appropriations for military construction, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, and for other purposes, and providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 8282) to impose sanctions with respect to the International Criminal Court engaged in any effort to investigate, arrest, detain, or prosecute any protected person of the United States and its allies."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on ordering the previous question on H. Res. 1269 and on agreeing to the resolution, if ordered, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of June 4.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 1269, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McGovern demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 1269.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 1269 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 8580) making appropriations for military construction, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, and for other purposes, and providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 8282) to impose sanctions with respect to the International Criminal Court engaged in any effort to investigate, arrest, detain, or prosecute any protected person of the United States and its allies."

actions-list.header: Commission on Reform and Modernization of the Department of State
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to the provisions of Public Law 117-263, and jointly with the Senate Republican Leader, the Majority Leader appointed the Honorable Bill Hagerty of Tennessee.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Kennedy to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Collins to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
